titleStmt.title: Τhe application of oxidized carbon derived from Luffa cylindrica for caffeine removal. Equilibrium, thermodynamic, kinetic and mechanistic analysis

analytic.title: Τhe application of oxidized carbon derived from Luffa cylindrica for caffeine removal. Equilibrium, thermodynamic, kinetic and mechanistic analysis

biblStruct.note: Received 20 September 2019 Received in revised form 2 November 2019 Accepted 5 November 2019

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Caffeine Oxidized Luffa cylindrica carbon Isotherms Mechanism Kinetic and thermodynamic studies

abstract.p: The present work investigates the adsorption of caffeine (CF) by oxidized carbon derived from Luffa cylindrica (OLC). Batch equilibrium experiments were carried out and the effect of adsorption parameters such as pH, contact time, temperature and ionic strength, have been investigated and discussed in detail. Maximum adsorption efficiency was observed at pH 4.0 and the adsorption of CF onto OLC reached equilibrium after 80 min. The kinetic experimental data followed the pseudo-second-order kinetic model and the equilibrium adsorption data fitted well to both Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models. The maximum adsorption capacity was estimated to be 59.9 mg/g at pH 4 and 298 K. Increasing ionic strength from 0 to 1 M NaClO led to a significant decline of the maximum adsorption capacity up to 50%. Thermodynamic studies revealed that the adsorption of CF onto OLC was spontaneous, exothermic with increasing randomness in the solid/solution system interface. The adsorption of CF on OLC at pH values between 4 and 10.4 seems to occur mainly via electrostatic attraction between the negative OLC surface and cationic form of CF. At pH values lower from 3 and higher from 10.4 other mechanisms such as pi-cation and dipol-dipol interactions may determine the CF adsorption on oxidized carbon surfaces.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Today, caffeine (1,3,7-trimethylxanthine) is assumed to be the most widely consumed psychostimulant in the world [1]. Approximately 80% of the world population consumes a caffeinated product daily [2]. Caffeine (CF) is a naturally occurring chemical compound found in coffee beans, tea leaves, cocoa beans, and kola nuts [3] and is also a content of various beverages (such as coffee, tea, caffeinated soft drinks, energy drinks) and of variety food products (chocolate, baked pastries, ice creams, sweets) [4]. Cold and flu remedies, also sometimes contain caffeine [5]. It is widely known that caffeine consumption stimulates the central nervous system that rejuvenates the body temporarily and restores alertness [6]. Caffeine is quickly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, and is almost completely metabolised in the liver [7] and only about 3% of a person's caffeine intake is excreted actually unchanged in the urine [8].

Generally, CF enters wastewaters through human urine [9] and/or from the direct disposal of caffeinated products that are discharged through household pipelines or sewers [8]. CF has been detected in many aqueous matrixes such as influent and effluent water from wastewater plants (WWTPs), groundwater, rivers and lakes, and seawater. Baker and Kasprzyk-Hordern [10] concluded that the median concentration of CF detected in WWTPs influents and effluents in the UK was 23,778.4 ng/L and 1744.2 ng/L, respectively. Lapworth et al. [11] found that the highest concentration of CF detected in raw groundwater samples in the Chalk aquifers of England and France, were 1.7 μg/L and 0.15 μg/L, respectively. Sodré et al. examined the presence of CF of an urban drinking water reservoir (Paranoá Lake) and the average concentration of CF was estimated to be 53 ng/L [12]. In another study in Brazil the respective data showed that the CF levels ranged from 1.8 ng/L to above 2 μg/L and from 40 ng/L to about 19 μg/L in drinking water and source waters, respectively [13]. In seawater samples collected from the Portuguese coastal area, the CF concentration varied between 18.0 ng/L and 525 ng/L [14]. In addition, CF is the earliest micropollutant used as indicator to detect untreated wastewater contamination as it is removed up to 99% during wastewater treatment [15].

Moreover, there are many studies indicating that the presence of CF contributes to coral bleaching. Coral bleaching is a phenomenon that takes place when the host corals expel the zooxanthellae due to break down of the symbiotic relationship under specific environmental stresses [16]. The coral bleaching has ecological, economical and social impacts. For example, coral reefs a) provide food, jobs and income to local communities [17], b) provide a habitat for marine species [18], c) protect from erosion and flooding [19] and d) support educational and research activities [20]. Sawyer and Muscatine [21], concluded that the presence of CF has a positive effect on corals bleaching, causing detachment of host cells from corals due to changes occurred by CF in the level of protein phosphorylation in anemones [22]. Pollack et al. [23] concluded that exposure to CF may exacerbate the effects of other environmental stressors on corals, making them more apt in coral bleaching. Other studies used stress biomarkers to examine the toxicity of CF [24], such as Heat shock protein 70 (Hsp70) [25] and lysosomal membrane stability (LMS) [26,27]. The exposure to CF showed an upregulation of Hsp70 in mussel Mytilus californianus [25] and also a destabilization of lysosomal membranes in the clam Ruditapes philippinarum [26] and the crab Carcinus maenas [27].

Based on the above, the presence of increased amounts of CF in wastewaters could be under circumstances a major environmental issue and therefore CF has to be removed from wastewaters prior to their discharge.

Adsorption techniques have been widely used as an effective alternative for the elimination of various pollutants from wastewater [28][29][30]. In comparison to other methods, adsorption based technologies are considered to be more attractive because of convenience, easy operation and simplicity of design [31]. There are various adsorbents applied for CF removal such as hydrochars obtained via hydrothermal carbonisation of pistachio shells [32], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [33], carbon xerogels [34] graphene nanoplatelets GNPs [35] and others.

The vegetable sponge (Luffa cylindrica) is a natural, low cost, ecofriendly, non-toxic, biodegradable and abundant material [36]. Luffa sponge, is a lignocellulosic materials that contains mainly cellulose, hemicelluloses and lignin [37], and consists of crisscrossed fibers forming a three-dimensional reticular structure [38]. Tanobe et al. found that the fibers of Luffa cylindrica contain 82.4% holocellulose, 63% a-cellulose, 19.4% hemicellulose, and 11.2% lignin [39]. Because of this unique structure of fibrous vascular system, Luffa cylindrica has been effectively applied to remove dyes [40][41][42][43], heavy metals [36,[44][45][46] and other toxic pollutants (such as phenols [47] and cyanide [48]) from aqueous solutions.

To the best of our knowledge, Luffa cylindrica-based adsorbents have never been studied before for CF removal. Preliminary studies were conducted using raw Luffa cylindrica (RLC), carbonized LC (CLC) and oxidized carbon (HNO M, 3 h, 80°C) derived from LC (OLC) for CF removal. The results showed that the % relative adsorption was decreased in the following order: OLC (56%) N CLC (27%) N RLC (2%). These results suggesting the high affinity of CF with carboxylic moieties that are mainly present on the OLC surface. The aims of this study was to examine the removal of CF from aqueous solution by OLC adsorbent. For this purpose, batch equilibrium studies were conducted in order to examine the effect of various parameters such as: pH, contact time, initial concentration and ionic strength on the CF adsorption. Moreover, thermodynamic and kinetic studies were performed, and the corresponding data have been evaluated to better understand and describe the adsorption mechanism.

div.head: Material, chemicals and equipment
div.p: The preparation and full characterization of OLC are presented in a previous work by Liatsou et al. [49]. The particle fraction between 500 μm and 50 μm was used for the adsorption experiments.

All chemicals used in this study were of analytical reagent grade. The stock CF solutions were prepared by dissolving the appropriate amounts of CF (Caffeine powder, ReagentPlus®, C0750 Sigma-Aldrich, putity (HPLC): ≥99%) in distilled water. CF concentration in solution was determined by means of a UV-Vis absorption spectrophotometer (UV 2401 PC Shimadzu) and the organic functional groups of OLC and CF-OLC were detected by Fourier Transform Infrared spectra (FTIR, spectrometer 8900,12 Shimadzu).

div.head: Batch experiments
div.p: Adsorption studies were conducted by equilibrating 0.05 g of OLC with 30 mL of CF solutions of the desired concentration in 50 mL plastic tubes. The content of the tubes was agitated on an orbital shaker at 125 rpm at constant temperatures. After shaking, the suspensions were filtered and the residual CF concentration was determined by spectrophotometry using a UV-Vis absorption spectrophotometer. The amount of CF adsorbed at time t and at equilibrium time, q t (mg/g) and q e (mg/g), were evaluated using the Eqs. 1and 2, respectively:
div.formula: q t ¼ C i −C t ð Þ V m ð1Þ q e ¼ C i −C e ð Þ V mð2Þ
div.p: where C i (mg/L) is the initial CF concentration in the solution, C t (mg/L) and C e (mg/L) are the final CF concentrations in solution at time t and at equilibrium, respectively. V (L) is the solution volume and m (g) is the dry weight of the adsorbent. The experiments were performed in triplicate and the mean values of the results have been used for data evaluation. Generally, the relative uncertainty of the values was below 10%.The effect of pH on the CF adsorption by OLC was examined in the pH range between 1 and 12 (adjusted by 0.01 to 1 M HClO or NaOH) at a CF concentration of 45 mg/L at 298 K and following 48 h of equilibration time. The effect of contact time was explored using a CF concentration of 45 mg/L at 298 K and pH 4.0, following adsorption in successive time intervals between 1 and 240 min. The effect of temperature and adsorption isotherms were examined at pH 4.0, at CF concentrations ranging from to 500 mg/L at 298, 313 and 323 K, following 24 h of equilibration time. The impact of ionic strength (0 M ≤ [NaClO 4 ] ≤ 1 M) were tested using a CF concentration of 45 mg/L at 298 K and at pH 4.0, following h equilibration time.

div.head: Effect of pH
div.p: The solution pH plays a key role during the adsorption process because it affects the charge of the adsorbent surface, the degree of ionization of the adsorbate molecules and the speciation of CF in the solution. The pH effect on the adsorption of CF onto OLC was studied by changing the pH values in the pH range between 1 and 12, and the corresponding results are presented in Fig. 1. The adsorption was found to increase slightly from pH 1 to pH 4 and then to decrease continuously up to pH 8.

Similar adsorption behavior of CF adsorbed by activated carbon is described in literature studies. Beltrame et al. [50] found that the adsorption of CF by mesoporous activated carbon fibers prepared from pineapple plant leaves (pH studied range 2-9) was high until pH 7 and then it decreased at pH 8 and pH 9. Portinho et al. [51] concluded that the pH has a small effect on CF adsorption by grape stalk activated carbon and the maximum adsorption was observed at pH 4 (19.575 mg/g) and the lower at pH 10 (19.429 mg/g). The phenomenological increase of the relative adsorption observed at pH 12 is most probably attributed to the degradation of CF under strong alkaline conditions as indicated by time-depended stability experiments of CF solutions at pH 12 (Fig. 2). Edwards et al. [6] concluded from experimental data that caffeine is decomposed, transformed or mineralized, within minutes to hours under strong alkaline conditions and high temperatures.

div.head: Effect of contact time and kinetic modeling
div.p: The effect of contact time on the adsorption capacity of CF onto OLC is illustrated in Fig. 3. According to the data, the adsorption is very fast in the first 10 min (q t = 11.94 mg/g) and with progressing contact time the adsorption rate decreases gradually until equilibrium is achieved after 80 min (q t = 14.99 mg/g). For higher contact times (N80 min) no significant changes in adsorption capacity were noticed until min (q t = 15.33 mg/g). The two-step kinetic pattern, which was observed, can be attributed to the large number of vacant binding sites that are available for adsorption at initial stages and decrease with time. In addition, repulsive forces between solute CF molecules on the adsorbent's surface and in interphase aqueous solution may affect the adsorption kinetics [52].

The evaluation of the uptake rate of the target pollutant onto the adsorbent is a crucial parameter for the effective design and potential scale-up of an adsorption processes from lab to industrial (e.g. water treatment plant) [53]. In this context, the experimental kinetic data were fitted with the pseudo-first-order (Eq. (3)) [54] and pseudosecond-order kinetic (Eq. (4)) models [55,56], in their linearized form:
div.formula: ln q e −q t ð Þ¼ ln q e −k 1 tð3Þ
div.p: where q e (mg/g) and q t are the amounts of adsorbed CF on the OLC at the equilibrium and at any time t, respectively; k 1 (min −1 ) is rate constant of the first-order adsorption. The q e,cal1 and k 1 can be calculated from the slopes and the intercept of the plot ln(q e − q t ) versus t.
div.formula: t q t ¼ 1 k 2 q e 2 þ 1 q e tð4Þ
div.p: where q e (mg/g) and q t are the amounts of adsorbed CF on the OLC at the equilibrium and at any time t, respectively; k 2 (g/mg min) is the rate constant of pseudo-second adsorption. The q e,cal2 and k 2 can be calculated from the slopes and the intercept of the plot t q t versus t.

The constants of the kinetic models have been estimated to be k = 0.036 min −1 (q e,cal1 = 5.97 mg/g and R 2 = 0.944) and k 2 = 0.022 g/mg min (q e,cal2 = 15.43 mg/g and R 2 = 0.999) for the pseudofirst-order and the pseudo-second-order kinetic model, respectively. It is clear that the pseudo-second-order kinetic model fits the experimental kinetic data better as indicated by the higher R 2 values and the corresponding calculated equilibrium adsorption capacity (q e,cal2 = 15.43), which is closer to the experimental one (q e,exp = 15.33 mg/g). This is in line with the use of pseudo-second-order kinetics to describe CF adsorption on activated carbon fibers prepared from pineapple plant leaves [50], graphene nanoplatelets [35], Multi-Wall Carbon Nanotubes [57] and sepiolite [58]. On the contrary, the adsorption of CF onto dead biomass of yeast Trichosporon sp. VITLN01 pretreated with Tween 80 is found to follow the pseudo-first-order kinetic model [59]. Fig. 4 displays the adsorption isotherms of CF onto OLC at three different temperatures (298, 313 and 323 K). The adsorption capacity was found to increase with increasing initial concentration and decrease with increasing temperature (Fig. 4). The increase of the initial concentration led to an increment of the adsorption capacity possible due to the large driving force of mass transfer which occurs at a high initial concentrations [60]. The decline in adsorption capacity with increasing temperature (Fig. 4) indicates on an exothermic process [60], which is in line with the principles/theory of adsorption assuming that adsorption is an exothermic process [61]. More specifically, at the highest studied concentration of 500 mg/L the adsorption was estimated to be 54.36, 49.06 and 43.54 mg/g at 298, 313 and 323 K, respectively. The reduction of the adsorption capacity with increasing temperature has been also reported by Bahrami et al. [57], Seedher and Sidhu [62], Ngeno et al. [63] and Al-Khateeb et al. [35], using Multi-Wall Carbon nanotubes, tea leaves, pyrolitically derived water hyacinth biochar and graphene nanoplatelets, respectively. Moreover, the experimental data have been fitted with the Langmuir [64] and Freundlich [65] isotherm models and the corresponding results are summarized in Table 1. The Langmuir isotherm model describes monolayer sorption at specific homogenous sites on the adsorbent. It can be expressed as follows:

div.head: Effect of temperature and isotherm modeling
div.formula: q e ¼ q m K L C e 1 þ K L C eð5Þ
div.p: where C e is the equilibrium concentration of the CF in solution (mg/L), q e is the amount of the CF adsorbed per gram of adsorbent at equilibrium (mg/g), q m is the maximum monolayer adsorption capacity (mg/ g) and K L is an equilibrium constant related to energy of adsorption. The Freundlich isotherm is applicable to non-ideal adsorption on heterogeneous, as well as, multilayer sorption, and it can be represented as:
div.formula: q e ¼ K F C e 1=n ð6Þ
div.p: where C e is the equilibrium concentration of the CF in solution (mg/L), q e is the amount of the CF adsorbed per gram of adsorbent at equilibrium (mg/g), Κ F and n are the Freundlich constants. Table 1 includes the evaluated constants and the corresponding regression coefficient values (R 2 ). The experimental data were found to fit well with both Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms models (R ≥ 0.98). The maximum monolayer adsorption capacity of the OLC for CF uptake was evaluated to be 59.88, 52.91 and 49.26 mg/g at 298, 313 and 323 K, respectively. This trend of the q max values is in agreement with the experimental results determined especially for higher CF concentrations.

Seedher and Sidhu [62], Ngeno et al. [63] and Sotelo et al. [58] also found that the experimental data fitted well also with both Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models using as adsorbent material tea leaves (q max = 435 mg/g), pyrolitically derived water hyacinth biochar (q max = 2.488 mg/g) and sepiolite (q max = 48.70 mg/g), respectively.

div.head: Effect of the ionic strength
div.p: The effect of the ionic strength using as electrolyte NaClO of different concentrations (0 M ≤ [NaClO 4 ] ≤ M) on the adsorption of CF onto the OLC was investigated and the results are shown in Fig. 5. According to Fig. 5, increasing NaClO concentration from 0 to 0.2 mol/L, a sharp decrease of the adsorption capacity of CF onto OLC is observed. For higher NaClO concentrations, the decrease of the CF adsorption is smoother and the adsorption capacity reaches a value of 8.13 mg/g when the ionic strength is 1 M (NaClO ). The significant decline (up to 50%) suggests the formation of outer-sphere surface complexes based on electrostatic interactions. This is attributed to the presence of the carboxylic moieties and the mechanism differs dramatically when the groups are not present. For instance, Al-Khateeb et al. [35] found that the increase of KNO 3 concentration from 0.001 M, to 0.008 M has led to a slight increase of the CF uptake by graphene nanoplatelets (GNPs'), indicating increased attraction due to π-π stacking between the neutral CAF (pK a = 14.0) and the GNPs' surface.

In addition, the FTIR spectrum of the caffeine prior and after adsorption ( Fig. 6) doesn't show any changes, indicating simple electrostatic interactions and no direct binding of the caffeine molecule on the OLC surface, which would result in changes regarding the geometry of the molecule and hence changes in the FTIR spectrum. The broadening of the peaks in the carbonyl region (1700 cm −1 -1500 cm −1 ) as well as the slopes observed in the spectrum of adsorbed caffeine are attributed to the spectrum of the oxidized carbon, which interferes with the CF spectrum. The CF spectrum is similar to the CF spectrum described in literature and contains all characteristic peaks such as the C\ \H and the -CH 3 streching vibration peaks at 3113 and 2955 cm −1 , respectively, the two carbonyl bands at 1702 and 1660 cm −1 , the band of the imidazole moiety at 1486 cm -l and the peaks at 1600 and 1548 cm -l , which correspond to pyrimidine ring vibrations [66]. On the other hand, the OLC spectrum contains the characteristic peaks of the oxidized carbon materials at 1630 cm −1 corresponds to the bending vibrations of adsorbed water molecules, whereas the peak at 1720 cm −1 and 1600 cm −1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of the carboxylic C\ \O moiety v (C\ \O) and the peaks observed at 1230 cm −1 are to the bending vibrations of C\ \O [49]. These results are in agreement with the results obtained from experiments related to the effect of ionic strength/salinity Table 1 Parameters evaluated applying the Langmuir and Freundlich models to CF adsorption data at 298, 313 and 323 K. Experimental conditions: contact time 24 h, pH 4, agitation rate 125 rpm, adsorbent/solution ratio 0.05 g/0.03 L, CF concentrations range from 10 to 500 mg/L.

div.head: Temperature (K)
div.p: Langmuir constants Freundlich constants on the adsorption efficiency of caffeine by the oxidized carbon surface (OLC) and indicate that caffeine binding occurs through electrostatic interactions.
div.formula: q m (mg/g) K L (L/mg) R 2 K F (mg/g)(L/mg)

div.head: Thermodynamic studies
div.p: The thermodynamic parameters, Gibbs free energy change ΔG 0 (kJ/ mol), the enthalpy change ΔH 0 (kJ/mol) and the entropy change ΔS 0 (J/mol K), were estimated using following equations [67][68][69]:
div.formula: ΔG 0 ¼ −RT ln K 0 e ð7Þ ΔG 0 ¼ ΔH 0 −TΔS 0 ð8Þ K 0 e ¼ 1000 Á K L Á MW adsorbate Á Adsorbate ½ 0 γð9Þ
div.p: where, R is the gas constant (8.314 J/mol K), T is the absolute temperature (K), K e 0 is thermodynamic equilibrium constant. K L was obtained by

Langmuir isotherm model, MW adsorbate is the molecular weight of CF (194.19 g/mol), [Adsorbate] 0 is the standard concentration of the adsorbate (1 mol/L) and γ is the coefficient of activity of the adsorbate (dimensionless). To consider that the activity coefficient is unitary (equal to 1), we considered that the adsorbate solution is very diluted. The ΔH°and ΔS°values can be calculated from the slope and the intercept of a plot of ΔG°versus T [70,71] (figure not shown, R = −0.94 or R 2 = 0.88). The ΔG 0 were estimated to be −20.16, −21.42, −21.51 at 298, 313 and 323 K, respectively, suggesting that the adsorption of CF onto OLC is a spontaneous process. The ΔH 0 and the ΔS 0 were found to be −3.47 kJ/mol and 0.056 kJ/mol K, respectively. The negative value of ΔH 0 indicates that the adsorption of CF onto OLC is an exothermic process supporting the previous results obtained from the temperature effect on the adsorption capacity. The positive results of the ΔS 0 imply increasing randomness in the solid/solution system interface during the adsorption process. Beltrame et al. [50] and Lakshmi and Das [59] who used mesoporous activated carbon fibers prepared from pineapple plant leaves and pre-treated dead biomass of yeast Trichosporon sp. VITLN01, respectively as adsorbents for CF uptake, have also concluded that the adsorption is spontaneous, exothermic with increasing randomness. Fig. 7 summarizes graphically the predominant CF species in the two pH regions determined by the pKa of caffeine (pKa = 10.4). Below pH 10.4 the protonated form and above pH 10.4 the deprotonated form are the dominant caffeine species in solution. In addition, Fig. 7 includes also the pH regions in which the protonated and the deprotonated form of the surface carboxylic groups are predominant. It has to be noted that due to the polyelectrolyte character of the biochar acidic system, the pKa value is not a specific one but takes basically values between 3 and 4, assuming that above pH 4, the anionic carboxylate form is the predominant surface species. It is clear that in the pH region between 4 and 10.4 the caffeine exists in its cationic form and the OLC surface is negatively charged due to the predominance of the negatively charged carboxylate moieties, suggesting electrostatic attraction between the adsorbate and the adsorbent. This is in agreement with the experimental results, which indicate that the adsorption of caffeine on the biochar surface in the respective pH region is basically based on electrostatic interaction.

div.head: Mechanism of the adsorption caffeine
div.p: The significance of electrostatic interaction between the anionic carboxylate moieties on the OLC surface and the cat ionic caffeine species is supported also by the fact that when the carbonized LC (CLC) is used as adsorbent the relative adsorption is significantly lower (27%) compared to the oxidized carbon (56%) under similar conditions. The two adsorbents differ from one another basically in the carboxylic moieties, which are formed by oxidation of the CLC and are present basically on the surface of the oxidized material. Other types of interaction between the adsorbate and the adsorbent could be dipol-dipol interactions and hydrogen bridges, which may play a significant role in the pH region below pH 3 and above pH 10.4.

div.head: Conclusions and future work
div.p: The results showed that the OLC can efficiently remove CF from aqueous solutions. Compared to non-oxidized carbon obtained from Luffa cylindrica, the oxidized carbon (OLC) presented significantly higher adsorption capacity attributed to the increased chemical affinity of cationic CF species with negatively charged carboxylate moieties. The adsorption was found to be affected significant by pH, contact time, temperature and ionic strength. The maximum monolayer adsorption capacity obtained from Langmuir isotherm was 59.9 mg/g at pH 4 and 298 K. At pH values below 3 and above 10.4, dipol-dipol interactions and hydrogen bridges, may play significant role in the adsorption process. In the pH region between 4 and 10.4, the adsorption of CF occurs predominantly via electrostatic attraction. Thermodynamic studies showed that the adsorption of CF was a spontaneous and exothermic. Future work may include the study of the synergistic or competitive Fig. 6. FTIR spectra of OLC, CF adsorbed on OLC and CF. Experimental conditions: pH 4.0, initial concentration 1000 mg/L, contact time 24 h, adsorbent/solution ratio 0.05 g/0.03 L, agitation rate 125 rpm, temperature 298 K (n = 3). Fig. 7. pH-dependend species distribution of CF and surface carboxylic moieties and schematic illustration of the main interaction mechanism between CF and the surface active groups. effect of other pollutants on CF adsorption by OLC, as well as the investigation of CF adsorption by using real wastewater.

div.head: Declaration of competing interest
div.p: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest regarding the publication of this article.

figure.figDesc: Effect of pH on adsorption of CF on OLC. Experimental conditions: contact time 48 h, initial metal concentration 45 mg/L, adsorbent/solution ratio 0.05 g/0.03 L, agitation rate rpm, temperature 298 K (n = 3). Effect of time on degradation of CF. Experimental conditions: pH 12, initial metal concentration 45 mg/L, temperature 298 K, in the absence of light (n = 2).

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Effect of contact time on the adsorption of CF on OLC. Experimental conditions: pH 4.0, initial metal concentration 45 mg/L, adsorbent/solution ratio 0.05 g/0.03 L, agitation rate 125 rpm, temperature 298 K (n = 2).

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Adsorption isotherms of CF on OLC at different temperatures (298, 313 and 323 K) and varying initial concentration of CF in solution (10-500 mg/L). Experimental conditions: contact time 24 h, pH 4.0, adsorbent/solution ratio 0.05 g/0.03 L, agitation rate 125 rpm (n = 3).

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: The effect of solution ionic strength (NaClO concentration ranged from 0 to 1 mol/L) on the adsorption of CF onto OLC surface. Experimental conditions: pH 4.0, initial concentration 45 mg/L, contact time 24 h, adsorbent/solution ratio 0.05 g/0.03 L, agitation rate 125 rpm, temperature 298 K (n = 3).
